LAUNCH OF PARLIAMENT HOMEPAGE
ON INTERNET
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


     Mr Speaker: I am pleased to inform hon. Members that after the adjournment today, the Parliament Homepage will be officially launched on the Internet.

    Singaporeans have always been kept well-informed of Parliamentary proceedings. Our newspapers carry detailed reports of the debates in the House and television has conveyed visual images of the cut and thrust of our debates into the living rooms of our people. The media has served the people well by providing sufficient opportunities for everyone to keep abreast of the debates and decisions of the House.

    Today, with Internet, we stand at the threshold of another media revolution. In 1995, the Minister for Information and the Arts estimated that there were 26,000 Internet subscribers in Singapore. A year later, we have around 100,000 Internet subscribers, and the number is growing fast. Internet is rapidly evolving into not only a rich source of information but also an important tool for communication.

    The time is right for Parliament now to reach out to Singaporeans through Internet. It is in line with Singapore's vision for IT 2000 and the Public Service's goals for PS21. It is consistent with our policy of promoting open, fair and transparent institutional systems. Through Internet, the world-at-large can gain insights into our Parliamentary system.

Column: 9

More importantly though, we hope to strengthen the bonds between the people and our law-makers.

    Our Homepage aims to do this by complementing the newspaper reports and televised proceedings. While these media can convey the logic behind an argument and the passions of a debate, it cannot be fully appreciated or understood unless one is aware of the processes of Parliament.

    To achieve this, our Homepage will be divided into two chapters: firstly, the Archival chapter which will contain pictures, interesting snippets and facts on Parliament's history, organisational structures and functions; and secondly, the Current Topics chapter which will list the business of the House for the next sitting. Together with the newspaper reports and televised debates, we can provide a more holistic view of the Parliamentary process.

    We will continue to explore new technology and apply it when appropriate, for example, the incorporation of sound and moving images in our Homepage and having our Hansard on-line through Government Intranet and Lawnet. We will also exploit other means of communication. To this end, I am happy to announce that Parliament will also be publishing a booklet version of our Homepage to be distributed to visitors on sitting days, and to schools and public libraries.

    It is my pleasure to extend an invitation to hon. Members and the press to join me later in the Government Parliamentary Party's Conference Room for the launch of the Parliament Homepage on the Internet.

ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FOREIGNERS BUYING PROPERTY IN SINGAPORE
(Imposition of levy)


    1. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Minister for National Development if he will consider introducing measures to curb property speculation such as that of imposing a levy on foreigners buying property in Singapore.

Column: 10

PROPERTY SPECULATION AND FOREIGN OWNERSHIP OF PRIVATE CONDOMINIUMS


    2. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for National Development whether there is a need to introduce further measures to curb property speculation and to limit foreign ownership of private condominiums.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I have your permission to take Question Nos. 1 and 2 together?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the MPs have raised two separate issues: (1) limiting foreign ownership of properties, and (2) curbing property speculation.

    The policy on foreign ownership of property in Singapore is set out under the Residential Properties Act, passed in 1976. Foreign investors are allowed to invest freely in commercial and industrial properties. For residential properties, foreigners can apply for a licence to develop, but can only purchase condominiums and apartments which are over six storeys. In other words, foreigners are currently excluded from 93% of the total housing stock in Singapore: HDB flats, landed properties, and apartments below six storeys. Foreigners have access to only 7% of the total housing stock.

    Our economic development strategy succeeded because we encouraged foreign investment in Singapore, including foreign investment in property development. Allowing foreigners to buy private residential properties has encouraged foreign talent to bring their assets and their families to Singapore, and contribute in many other ways to our economy.

    Foreigners own about 13,000 units, or less than 2% of the total housing stock in Singapore. If we look at the private property segment of about 140,000 units, foreigners own about 9%.

    The question is whether 2% of total housing stock, or 9% of private residential properties, is too high a percentage for foreigners to own in an open market

Column: 11

economy like Singapore. We need and have thrived on the free movement of capital, talent and expertise.

    Foreign buyers are not the principal cause of the property price increases. Other basic factors are:

    1) The high growth of incomes and savings among Singaporeans;

    2) The increase in resale values of HDB flats, following the liberalisation of HDB's financing rules for resale flats. This has increased the number of HDB owners who can afford to upgrade to or invest in private properties;

    3) Low interest rates and readily available mortgage financing; and

    4) The prevailing mood of the market, and the confidence that Singapore will enjoy high economic growth and political stability for the foreseeable future. The recent spate of letters and reports in the press on foreign ownership of properties has blown the issue of foreign buyers out of proportion.

    Besides foreigners, "speculators" have also been blamed for rising property prices. "Speculators" are people who buy properties to resell at a profit after a short holding period, instead of for long term investment or living in. There always is some property speculation, in falling as well as rising markets. Within limits, these "speculators" play a useful intermediary role. They help the property market to function efficiently and bridge the gap between long term buyers and long term sellers.

    But in a rising market, property speculation can get out of hand. Excessive speculation can create a false mood of euphoria, and push prices up higher than long term fundamentals can justify. Eventually, this will result in a property market collapse, which can seriously damage the rest of the economy. In Japan, when the bubble burst, not only did many home buyers on mortgages suffer, but property companies went bankrupt and many

Column: 12

banks incurred huge losses on huge loans on properties and had to be bailed out by the government.

    The Government is therefore carefully monitoring the situation. We are examining current market practices to see whether we need to adjust the rules on foreign ownership, or dampen excessive property speculation. However, any steps affecting the property market should only be taken after the most careful consideration. Acting hastily and unwisely will shake the faith of investors, local and foreign, in the Government, and undermine the confidence of the market.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Sir, does the Minister think that the Residential Properties Act, 1976, need to be further amended at this point of time? Secondly, will he consider the following measures:

    a) imposing a minimum holding period on foreign buyers;

    b) no resale of uncompleted units in all condominiums for three years; and

    c) all developers should report to the Tax Department all resale transactions with details of the resale prices.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, the Residential Properties Act, passed in 1976, has served us well all these 20 years. I think it will be very unwise to tinker with the Act without studying the situation very carefully. As I have said, the Government is monitoring the situation. The percentage of foreign ownership is not something that has changed over the years. The number has remained fairly constant. It is not something that has gone up dramatically in the last few years. So we would not want to amend the Residential Properties Act unless there are very good reasons for it.

    As I have explained in my answer, the Act has served us well. We have kept an open economy which encourages foreign investment in Singapore, both in other sectors as well as in the property sector, and the number of foreign purchases in the residential property market is not something that has turned out to be very large. So it will be wise not to tinker with the Act.

Column: 13



     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): In the light of escalation of prices of private residential properties, is the Minister of the view that there is a possibility that Singaporeans have over-invested in private properties?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, buying private properties is an individual decision by the investors. As far as the financial market and the banking sector are concerned, there are sufficient rules to make sure that prudence is exercised in the borrowings to purchase properties. Right now, the rules on mortgage loans have made sure that the financial sector exercises due prudence in giving out such loans. Whether or not individuals are over-extended in buying properties, we will have to leave it to the individual.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: The Minister mentioned just now that one of the factors which has resulted in the increase in private residential property prices is that loans are readily available. Looking at the nation as a whole and that the financial sector is prepared and willing to give the loans, are we as a nation over-invested in property?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, macro-economists have some rules of thumb about investment in property as a fixed investment. If I remember the numbers correctly, as a percentage of our GDP, investment in fixed assets, primarily properties, is not unduly high in Singapore at this stage of our development. If I were to answer his question, we can look at it in different parameters.

    The first parameter is, in a country's economic development, what proportion of its investment is in property and what investment is in other economic sectors. Based on the statistics that we have, our share of GDP in fixed property investment is not unduly high at our stage of development.

    The second parameter that we can look at is: are we over-extended as a country in terms of mortgage loans on property? Again, the banking system is well regulated. There are sufficient rules in place to make sure that the credit-worthiness of borrowers is assessed correctly and limits

Column: 14

are put on the amount that they can borrow. These are prudent rules. The bank association on their own have decided to reduce the ceiling of the loans in line with the rising property prices. It shows that the financial market is acting cautiously and there is no extension of the mortgage loan sector.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, how about looking from the parameter of our CPF savings?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If you look at the individual, whether or not he has over-extended, as I say, that is up to the individual, ie, what proportion of his savings he wants to put in property and what proportion in other assets. If you look at the total country's investment, ie, the country's net savings translated into investments, as I said earlier, that percentage does not show that we are over-investing in properties.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, I would like to declare my interest as a property developer.

    Sir, would the Minister agree with me that today, banks in Singapore are not allowed to lend Singapore dollars to foreigners wishing to buy property in Singapore? Would the Minister also agree with me that no country had really been successful in putting an imposition on foreign purchase of property in their own home markets, except by causing a blip in the market due to some initial loss of confidence whereas subsequently the fundamentals take over, and the market continues on, because of the fundamental reasons of that particular country?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: I am afraid I lost him somewhere along the line. But I can agree with what he said about the rules of foreigners borrowing in our markets. The question that Mr Low wants answered is this notion that, as a country, we are over-extending ourselves in property. I think this is a macro-economic question. You look at your country's fixed investments, and you ask yourself what percentage is put in different so-called productive assets and non-productive assets. I think what he is trying to get is that we are putting too much in property, which is non-productive assets.

Column: 15



    The gross investment in Singapore is very high. This translates from our very high rate of savings and that results in a very high rate of investment for macro-economic growth. Out of these domestic investments, you will notice that a high percentage of it goes into infrastructure. A lot of our Government's development expenditure goes into port, airport expansion and roads. These are probably what you will consider productive investments. So if you look at the stage of our development today, our investment in infrastructure and properties is not unduly high. And if you look at the investment in property, and a high percentage of this is in public housing, you can reach the conclusion that our actual investment in private property is also not very high.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tampines GRC): Sir, first, I would like to declare my pecuniary interest as a managing director of a public-listed company involved in property development.

    Three questions for the Minister. Firstly, will he enlighten the House on the percentage of foreign ownership of private property, say, five years ago, compared to the 9% today?

    Secondly, will the URA publish these numbers on a regular basis, so that there will be no wrong perception in the public's mind as to the extent of foreign ownership of private property?

    The last question, Sir, is this: will he like to paint a scenario of what will be the problem if we impose sudden curbs on foreign ownership of property? In other words, what impact will it have on the current property market and property owners?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Since the enactment of the Residential Properties Act in 1976, ownership of properties by foreigners has never been a big issue because 93% of our properties are protected and not made available to foreigners. So there has never been a need to monitor the percentages of foreign ownership of our properties in a regular way. We have not had these data five years ago. URA started monitoring

Column: 16

the purchases of foreigners in the new launches since 1994, and the percentage of foreigners has remained consistently in the same range, between 17% and 28% of new properties, ie, of all condominiums. So when you restrict ownership of private property, and 93% of properties in Singapore are not available to foreigners, then, of course, foreigners can only buy the remaining 7%. And out of the 7% private condominiums, for new launches, foreigners take up between 17% and 28% of these properties. These numbers were released in 1994 and the numbers have remained consistent. It has gone up; it has gone down, depending on each quarter, but it has hovered around this percentage. So there has not been a major shift in the ownership of private properties by foreigners.

    As to what will be the impact on the property market if we were to restrict foreigners on the purchase of private property in Singapore, I would like to caution that there are several implications. The first implication is the level of confidence on the policies and the market that we operate in Singapore. Singapore has thrived because we have kept our economy open, even in those days when conventional wisdom in many countries kept their markets closed. We wisely kept our markets open, encouraged foreign investments in Singapore, and we had benefited from that policy. If we were to react unwisely now and close the market, this sends a wrong signal about the openness of our markets. So I would hasten to make any drastic changes to the Residential Properties Act when the factors and the situation in terms of foreign ownership of our properties do not warrant such a drastic change.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Two supplementary questions. First, Sir, I know that the Australian government has allowed foreigners to invest freely in the property market but has imposed certain restrictions on sale of property. They could only sell to Australians, not foreigners. Will the Government consider some measure to that effect in the future, if there is a need?

    The second supplementary question is: would the Minister reveal the number and

Column: 17

percentage of foreign ownership of private residential condominiums in districts 9, 10 and 11?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: If Members start comparing Singapore with other countries, they will draw the conclusion that Singapore's property market is, in fact, more highly protected than the Australian market, because 93% of our market are not open to foreigners. The HDB sector and the landed property sector are not open to foreigners. So, in fact, only 7% are open to foreigners. When other countries, for example, Malaysia, put a levy on property, they are protecting the lower-priced properties. But in Singapore we do not need to do that because the HDB segment is already protected. Foreigners cannot compete to buy HDB properties.

    So if you restrict the sector which is open to foreigners, you are in fact making the situation worse. You are in fact making the sector even smaller and with the high level of foreign confidence in our Government, in our economy, foreigners going for properties in a smaller market will then accentuate the prices. Today, with foreigners being allowed to buy only private condominiums, I think that is the right approach because the lower segments and the landed properties are protected, so that foreigners cannot own land in Singapore. That is a sound policy. It has served us well since 1976 and there is no need to make any drastic changes unless foreigners are buying in very large numbers, and they are not.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, in view of the take-up rate of new properties by foreigners in the range of 17% and 28%, as disclosed by the Minister, will the Minister take this into account when the Planning Department or the URA releases the supply of land for tender?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: I would urge Members to look at this issue in its entire perspective. The very reason why the property markets have moved is because there is strong confidence in the Singapore economy, in the Singapore Government. If that confidence is not there, property prices will collapse. When we look at the new releases of land for

Column: 18

private condominiums, we take all these into consideration. First, the changing aspirations of Singaporeans and, therefore, we have moved from releasing 2,000 units to 6,000 units a year. Do not forget that not very long ago, less than seven or eight years ago, in the private property market, we were only talking about 4,000 units every year. And out of the 4,000 units, nobody quarrelled or discussed about foreign ownership in the 4,000 units. We have put in more land sales to raise the availability of such units to more than 10,000 now -- 6,000 by the Government and 4,000 from the land banks of private developers.

    So we have made private condominiums and private property more readily available to Singaporeans and, in so doing, Singaporeans now have better access to private property. As we track the purchases of Singaporeans and foreigners in the private property market, and we detect a strong demand for private property, Members can be assured that we will continue to adjust the supply to meet this demand. So the answer is, yes, we are monitoring this very closely and if indeed there is a greater demand for private property, the Government will adjust its land sales accordingly.

CUSTOMS ACT
(Amendment of provisions on forfeiture of vehicles)


    3. Dr Ker Sin Tze asked the Minister for Law whether the Government intends to introduce legislation to amend the provisions on forfeiture of vehicles in the Customs Act in view of the views expressed by the Chief Justice in the case of Public Prosecutor v M/s Serve You Motor Service that the legislature should consider making the necessary amendments.

     The Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government has carefully considered the views expressed by the Chief Justice in the case of Public Prosecutor v M/s Serve You Motor Service but has decided not to amend the Customs Act.

    Sir, in that case it concerned the effect of section 124(4) of the Customs Act which

Column: 19

provides that the District Judge shall order the goods to be forfeited on proof that an offence under this Act has been committed and that the goods were used in the commission of the offence. The District Judge decided that the court had the discretion not to order the forfeiture of a motor-lorry which was used in carrying 4,350 uncustomed cartons of cigarettes worth $137,246. The Public Prosecutor appealed as a matter of principle and the appeal was allowed by the Chief Justice who held that the forfeiture was mandatory under the clear words of the section. The Chief Justice expressed sympathy for the owners as they were not involved or implicated in the commission of the offence, nor did they know that the vehicle would be used for an unlawful purpose.

    Sir, we have studied the comments of the Chief Justice in this case very carefully. Indeed, even before this case, Government had begun a review in March last year of the issue of forfeiture of vehicles used in the commission of certain offences. This was because the issue first arose in another case of Toh Teong Seng. And in that case the Chief Justice (in the context of the Environmental Public Health Act), recognising that forfeiture would act as a deterrent to illegal dumping, commented, however, that forfeiture of vehicle was a disproportionate "substitute" punishment when the offence itself carried a fine not exceeding $1,000.

    The Chief Justice then had separately expressed his concerns to the Attorney-General and made some suggestions on how the Environmental Public Health Act could be improved to reflect its legislative goals. When the Attorney-General conveyed the Chief Justice's views to me as Minister for Law, I immediately wrote to the other Ministers in charge of similar legislation.     Sir, the Select Committee on the Advance Medical Directive (AMD) Bill received 14 written submissions. The Committee heard oral representation from 12 persons in respect of six of the written submissions. The Committee's Report has been circulated to Members of the House.

    Most of the points raised in the submissions are already catered for in the Bill presented earlier to Parliament. These include safeguards against euthanasia, the proper certification of terminal illness and the rights of patients who have not made directives.

    I wish to take this opportunity to reiterate three important points concerning the AMD. First, the purpose of the AMD is to allow the patient to make a choice in advance and not have the dying process prolonged by extraordinary life-sustaining treatment if he becomes terminally ill and mentally incompetent. While this is the patient's own decision, we will encourage the involvement of family members in the decision-making process and will emphasise this point in our public education programme.

    Second, the AMD is only applicable when the patient is "terminally ill". It applies only to those who are already in the process of dying and no longer able to decide for themselves. No one can force a patient to accept medical treatment against his wishes. All the AMD does is to enable him to express his wishes in advance while he is still mentally competent. Therefore, the concern that the directive may be used by some individuals to commit suicide is unwarranted. Notwithstanding this, the Bill clearly states that it does not condone nor authorise abetment of suicide, mercy killing or euthanasia. Sufficient safeguards have been incorporated into the Bill to prevent such abuses.

    Third, the directive does not affect the right of a patient who is mentally competent to make decisions concerning his own medical treatment. As long as the patient is able to express his wishes, doctors will act according to them whether or not he has made an AMD. For those who do not wish to make a

Column: 99

directive, the current practice will continue when they become terminally ill and mentally incompetent. Doctors will then make decisions in consultation with family members.

    Sir, I will now highlight the substantive amendments recommended by the Select Committee.

Witnessing the making of a Directive

    One representor asked whether the two witnesses required for the making of the directive should be present at the same time.

    The Select Committee felt that this had to be so logically, but to put it beyond doubt, the Bill has been amended to make this requirement clear.

Revocation of a Directive

    One representor commented that the requirement to have two witnesses for the revocation might not be necessary. This could result in a delay if one witness failed to report the revocation to the Registrar.

    The Committee agreed with the representor that the revocation of the directive should be made easy so that, if there is any doubt, we err on the side of prolonging life. The Bill has thus been amended to allow revocation with one witness, provided that the witness informs the Registrar in writing. Of course, the patient should also notify the Registrar if he is able to do so.

    As a counter-balance to the above amendment which makes revocation easier, a related amendment is made to give greater certainty to the medical practitioner who has to decide whether to act on a directive.

Medical Practitioners' involvement in the Directive

    The Committee shared the concern raised by some representors that the Bill did not explicitly exclude medical practitioners who might benefit from the death of the patient.

Column: 100



    The Bill has thus been amended to state that doctors who may benefit from the death of the patient will be excluded from being involved in the certification of terminal illness and in the execution of the directive.

Offence in causing another to make a Directive

    One representor pointed out that irresponsible family members might be able to pressure an elderly patient to make a directive without actually committing any offence under clause 14(1).

    The Committee shared the representor's concern and decided to amend the Bill to widen the scope of clause 14(1) to make it an offence to obtain a directive by "unconscionable conduct".

    Finally, it was pointed out by one representor that clause 15(3), requiring doctors to keep all information relating to the patient's making of a directive confidential, might hinder the doctor from counselling family members when the patient has already been determined to be terminally ill under clause 9.

    The Committee agreed that counselling family members is important when the directive is being executed. The Bill has been amended accordingly to allow doctors to divulge information about the patient's AMD to family members once the patient has been determined to be terminally ill under clause 9.

    Sir, the Ministry of Health will conduct a public education programme on various aspects of the AMD. We will involve civic organisations and community leaders. Doctors and relevant health care workers, in particular, will be trained on what their responsibilities are, and what advice they should give to their patients.
